not inferior to Aristotle, Pliny, or Buffon— The Habits, the Passions, the varieties, the physical properties, the customary Grecian nomenclature of the hunting dog, with thirty-six names of individual dogs male and female, are all included in thirty lines of beautiful and most harmonious versification.— A translator (it was Addison) who sunk under the difficulty of rendering this into English verse, ought not to have ventured to encounter the Metamorphoses of Ovid— I wished also to see the account of the metamorphosis of Arethusa— It is towards the close of the 5th book—translated by Maynwaring— There is much about Alpheus in it; but nothing about Doris— In Virgil’s 10th. Eclogue, Doris is the Sea— I found Summer heat in walking home— Sent a copy of the Mexican Documents to Benjamin Lundy, who had requested one of me, and a copy of the Postmaster General’s definitive answer to Luther Swan, declining to remove the Postmaster at Stoughton— I received the reporter Otis’s minutes of my speech on Saturday Night, and my tabular statement which I began to revise.
18. III:30. Wednesday.

Weather at summer heat— I had before I came from home received from Mr Lemuel Humphrey of Weymouth papers relating to three claims of revolutionary widow pensions. Lucy Holbrook Olive Lovell and Ruth Bates— In the first week after my arrival here, I had made application for them, with some others at the Pension Office; and shortly after had received answers concerning the claims of Lucy Holbrook and Olive Lovell, but none, concerning that of Ruth Bates— In the great hurry of business during the Session I had overlooked these papers, and neglected to communicate the result of the enquiries to Mr Humphrey. This morning I took his paper concerning Ruth Bates again to the Pension Office, and left it with Dr George W. Crump, who supplies the places of the Commissioner J. L Edwards during his absence— He himself was there, but said he was going immediately to the North upon business, and would leave me with the Doctor— To avoid however any further delay in answering Mr Humphrey upon the two other cases, I wrote to him enclosing the Commissioners Letter to me on that of Lucy Holbrook, and an extract from that relating to Olive Lovell, and I enclosed to him four printed circulars from the War Department relating to the execution of the last Pension Laws— After dinner I walked to Mr Frye’s; and spent an hour of the Evening with him— He gave me a check on the Bank of Washington, for 250 dollars—a drop in the bucket— Mr Frye, walked homeward with me as far as the corner of the President’s Square— On examining Mr Otis’s minutes of my Speech last Saturday Evening I find it will be necessary for me to write it out entirely, and I employed this Evening in revising the tabular Statement of the portions of the 4th. instalment due to the several States compared with the balances due from the late deposit Banks— This tabular statement formed the basis of my whole argument; and as there was a continual recurrence to arithmetical sums compared together it would have been impossible for a reporter far better qualified than Otis, to have taken it down correctly as I spoke.
19. III:30 Thursday.

Intense Summer— I called at the Bank of the Metropolis, and entered as a special deposit, the Speaker’s check for my pay— Then at the Bank of Washington, where I deposited Mr Frye’s check. Then at the Office of the National Intelligencer where I saw Mr Seaton—Featherstonhaugh, and John Mason junr. who came in and immediately went out— Featherstonhaugh was apparently much incensed against Mason, whom after he went out he charged with gross injustice to him for urging him to travel with him in the Cherokee Nation, and then making him pay half the expence of the Carriage— I wanted to consult the Register of debates in March 1834. for a passage in a Speech of mine, on the removal of the deposits, and I found it, under date of 17 March p. 3011— Early this evening Thomas J. Frye came suddenly into my chamber; to borrow 20 dollars till to-morrow Morning, which I accordingly lent him— Mrs Goods’s daughter Mary, was married this Evening, by the Revd Mr Fowler, in the front Parlour of my house, to a young man named Thomas Mitchell, a Shoemaker.— Mrs Goods asked me to allow the wedding to be here—to which I cheerfully consented.— Mrs Goods herself, Mrs Nowlan, Mrs Giusta—a little daughter of Mrs Goods; a young man, a companion of Mitchell, and a young woman, a friend of the bride, were all the company present— The ceremony performed by Mr Fowler was short—beginning with a prayer—not naming either of the parties, but calling them Mr and Miss—bidding them join hands while he pronounced the nuptial vows—using the formula of love, honour and obey for the woman, and closing with that deeply solemn injunction— I pronounce you man and wife, and those whom God hath joined, let not man put asunder.— I had some conversation with Mr Fowler, who told me that he had been spending some weeks in Virginia, during which Dr Laurie had supplied his pulpit; and the two Congregations had united in worship— He spoke of his predecessors, Bishop, Smith, Campbell and Baker, all of whom have been preachers at the Presbyterian Church since I have had a pew there, and expressed a strong wish that the two Churches, Dr Lauries and his own, both feeble might be united in one.— He spoke also of the dissensions in the presbyterian church, but said there was a flattering prospect of their being healed.
20. III:30. Friday.

Morning visit from Dr Huntt— He looks like a living skeleton, but says his health has been very much improved by a late excursion to the red sulphur Springs in Virginia— I went out in search of the residence of Mr James Whitcomb the Commissioner of the general Land-Office, but did not find it— He paid me a visit last Spring shortly after he came into the Office, introduced by Mr W. S. Smith— Not knowing who he was, my conversation with him was unsuitable and indiscreet— I wished now to return his visit, but could not find his house. I received this day from Alexander H. Everett a copy of his Address to the Philermenian Society of Brown University, at Providence the 4th. of last Month— I had been invited to deliver the Address, on this occasion, which I had fortunately declined; for as it was the day of the Meeting of Congress at their late Session, I could not have performed
performed the engagement, if I had undertaken it— Mr Everett’s Address is upon the moral character of the Literature of the last and present century, and was so deeply interesting that after once looking into it, I could not lay it aside, till I had gone wholly through it— Upon the whole it is an excellent spirited discourse, contrasting the characters of Hume, Voltaire, Grimm, D’Alembert and the School of the French Encyclopaedia, with the Philosophers of the Scotch-German and French schools of philosophy of the present age—with Stuart, Reid, Mackintosh, Brougham, Kant, Cousin and Madame de Stael— The treatment of the subject is not profound— He does not even name Bolingbroke, Quesnay, Diderot, nor Buffon and he scarcely notices Burke— He compares only the Literature of the last have of the 18th. with that of the first part of the 19th. century, not yet half expired— The idea of the comparison is ingenious, and it is treated with an excellent moral purpose. Examining the subject more closely it may be doubted whether the moral character of Literature at this time is so much improved over that of the last Century as he supposes— The philosophy of the French and German Schools is perhaps not more Christian, than that of Voltaire, certainly not so much so as that of Rousseau— Mr Everett urges that the peaceable and bloodless character of the revolutionary movements at this time, in France and England, is attributable to this purified morality of their Literature— There may be something in this— At least it deserves further meditation— The conclusion of the Discourse, is an eloquent and pathetic address to the young men, the members of the Society, exhorting them to adhere through life to the promotion and improvement of this pure moral principle; closing with the inscription on the Labarum of Constantine ΕΝ ΤΟΥΤΩ ΝΙΚΑ. By this conquer.
21. V. Saturday.

Antoine was here this morning, with my note to John Wilson, which he had endorsed; and which with the interest due upon it I now paid— He had also a bill for some new stair-carpeting purchased for this house, for which I asked him to wait a few weeks.— I called at the Bank of Washington, and drew a check upon the Bank of the Metropolis for the specie that I had deposited there— The Bank of Washington has resumed payment in specie of its own bills.— The Bank of the Metropolis has not and cannot— I have no confidence in the common honesty of its managers, and am unwilling to trust them with a special deposit— There was an advertisement in the Intelligencer this morning, that Treaties with the Sioux and the Sacs of the Missouri would be signed this morning at 11. O’Clock; and one with the Sacs and Foxes of the Mississippi at 1. O’Clock. and that a general council would be held at 3. O’Clock. The meetings to be at the Church in F. Street— I went out near one O’Clock—stop’d at the Church, but found none of the Indian diplomacy there— Returning from the Bank of Washington, I stop’d again; there were some women and children in the pews, waiting to see the Show, but none of the contracting parties— I came home; took an early dinner and soon after 3. O’Clock returned to the Church— It was then crowded and two or more of the tribes of Indians were seated on a stage floored over the tops of the pews from the pulpit to the front pews— They were at the right and left hand of the Secretary of War, Poinsett, who was standing in the centre in front of the pulpit, and investing the Chiefs one after the other with a large silver medal, which he hung over the shoulders of each of them suspended by a blue silk ribband
ribband— After which he made them a short farewell Speech; exhorting them to go home and keep the Peace with one another—expressing his pleasure at the conclusion of the Treaties with them; at their having stipulated for education and agricultural instruction—that a difficulty between the Sacs and Foxes and the Winebagoes had been amicably settled—and he promised that the engagements stipulated with them on his part should all be faithfully performed— As he spoke Sentence by Sentence, two Interpreters, one on each side explained to the respective tribes—Sacs and Foxes of the Mississippi, Sioux, Sacs and Ioways of the Missouri, and Winebagoes 74. in number, what he said; and each sentence was received with the usual Indian grunt— They then all successively shook hands with the Secretary of War and went away— Mr Pointsett’s manner, like his discourse was cold, stiff and formal— W. S. Coxe, whom I met there, observed to me that Governor Barbour, was better fitted for a Speech to Indian chiefs than Pointsett. I came home, and went to work upon my tabular computations; and in the Evening began to write out my Speech— Long evening visit from Mr Langtree; a fulsome flatterer— He urged me much to write for his Democratic review and magazine; but I told him that Literature was and in its nature must always be aristocratic—that democracy of numbers and literature were self-contradictory— Among the interpreters of these Winebago Indians was Major Thomas Boyd—a Son of George Boyd, and of my wife’s Sister Harriet— He came with Satterlee Clark junr to see me, but I was not at home, and they left a card.—
22. V. Sunday.

Morning service at the Presbyterian Church. Heard Mr Fowler, from Isaiah 25.1. “O Lord thou art my God; I will exalt thee, I will praise thy name: for thou hast done wonderful things; thy counsels of old are faithfulness and truth.”— The latter part of the verse Dr Laurie was in the pulpit, and old Mr and Mrs Nourse, in my pew— After Church I had a visit from my neighbour General Macomb— After dinner at St. John’s church Mr Hawley read the service for the 22d. Sunday after Trinity, and preached from Deuteronomy 32.9. “For the Lord’s portion is his people; Jacob is the lot of his inheritance— 10. He found him in a desert Land, and in the waste howling wilderness; he led him about, he instructed him, he kept him as the apple of his eye— 11. As an eagle stirreth up her nest, fluttereth over her young, spreadeth abroad her wings, taketh them, beareth them on her wings, 12. So the Lord alone did lead him, and there was no strange God with him”— The text was full of matter, but the Sermon was empty— Mrs Frye came home and sat some time with me; and I walked with her to Mrs Smith’s— I returned home early in the Evening, and continued writing out my Speech of Saturday the 14th. I read a pamphlet Letter, from William L. Stone to Dr Amariah Brigham, relating his visit to Providence Rhode-Island, where he witnessed the operations of animal magnetism, performed by Dr George Capron, upon Miss Loraina Brackett, a young woman from Dudley, Massachusetts— The account is as marvelous as the stories of the Cock-lane Ghost, the Miracles at the tomb of the Abbé Paris, or the Salem witcheries of the 17th. Century. The substance of the story is, that by the effect of certain cabalistic motions of a magnetiser, the patient, a person labouring under nervous disease, is lulled into profound sleep, and in that condition, is by the power of imagination
imagination, endowed with miraculous powers of loco-motion, and especially of vision— Dr Capron magnetized this young Lady into a profound sleep, in nine minutes of time; first making her walk in sleep about the house, and look at pictures with the back of her head turned to them— He next put her into a state of Clairvoyance, and then delivered her over to Mr Stone, who sat down by her side took her hands in his, and by agreement with her transported her through the air, to New-York, where they visited sundry places among which was Mr Stone’s own house. She saw every thing that was to be seen, and among them rarities never seen by any one else— Mr Stone’s narrative is much interspersed with argument to prove that he could not have been deceived or imposed upon— There is an appendix of additional evidence of the wonders of animal magnetism, which within a few months past has been exciting a degree of public attention somewhat alarming— I am apprehensive that there is danger of some great imposture’s being imposed upon the public credulity, and I cannot but meditate upon the fact, that the existence of this mysterious power of animal magnetism, has maintained itself in the minds of multitudes, more than have a century since its fallacy was detected by the Commission from the French Academy of Sciences in 1783. It is among the remarkable hallucinations of the human mind; and one of those in which the natural progress is from weakness to frailty—from frailty to vice—from Vice to Crime, and from crime to public calamity— Stone’s pamphlet is portentous— My morning and evening labours overply my faculties, and I had a restless and uneasy Night.
23. V. Monday

Mr Frye called on me this morning, and left with me a volume of the Laws of the District of Columbia, compiled by judge Cranch, and published in 1831. in the name of William A. Davis.— I wanted it, to examine the Charters of the several District Banks— Mr Frye told me that a requisition had gone, from the War to the Treasury Department for an issue of eighty thousand Dollars for the War in Florida— There was in the National Intelligencer this morning an advertisement, signed James H. Birch, and Edward Dyer Auctioneer—headed Sale of Slaves— A sale at public auction at 4 O’Clock this afternoon, of Dorcas Allen, and her two surviving children aged about 7. and 9. years (the other two having been killed by said Dorcas in a fit of insanity as found by the jury who lately acquitted her)— The advertisement further says that the said Slaves were purchased by Birch, on the 22d. of August last of Rezin Orme, warranted sound in body and in mind— That the terms of sale will be cash, as said slaves will be sold on account of said Rezin Orme, who refuses to retake the same and repay the purchase money, and who is notified to attend said sale, and if he thinks proper to bid for them, or retake them, as he prefers, upon refunding the money paid, and all expenses incurred, under the warranty given by him— I asked Mr Frye, what this advertisement meant— He seemed not to like to speak of it, but said the woman had been sold with her children to be sent to the South, and separated from her husband—that she had killed two of her children, by cutting their throats, and cut her own to kill herself, but in that had failed— That she had been tried at Alexandria, for the murder of her children, and acquitted on the ground of insanity— And that this sale now, was by the purchaser, at the expense of the seller, upon the warranty that she was
was sound in body and mind— Mr Frye brought me ten numbers of Niles’s Register, which had been sent to his house while I was absent last Summer, and of which I had obtained another set, supposing that they had been stopped during the recess— I took them to Niles’s Register Office, but he was not there— I called at the Office of the National Intelligencer and saw Mr Seaton—enquired of him concerning the advertisement of the Sale of Slaves, in the paper of this morning. He answered with reluctance, and told me the same story that I had heard from Mr Frye—adding that there was something very bad about it, but without telling me what it was— It is a case of Conscience with me, whether my duty requires or forbids me to pursue the enquiry in this case—to ascertain all the facts, and to expose them in all their turpitude to the world— The prohibition of the internal Slave-trade is within the Constitutional power of Congress, and in my opinion is among their incumbent duties— I have gone as far upon this article, the abolition of Slavery, as the public opinion of the free portion of the Union will bear—and so far that scarcely a slave holding member of the House dares to vote with me, upon any question— I have as yet been thoroughly sustained in my own State; but one step further, and I hazard my own standing and influence there; my own final overthrow, and the cause of Liberty itself for indefinite time—certainly for more than my remnant of life.— Were there in the House one member capable of taking the lead in this cause of universal emancipation, which is moving onward in the world, and in this country, I would withdraw from the contest, which will rage with increasing fury, as it draws to its crisis, but for the management of which my age, infirmities and approaching end totally disqualify me— There is no such man in the House— Seaton told me that he would publish my Speech of the 14th. instt. before that of 29. September, for the sake of giving variety to his readers. I bespoke 50 copies of it in pamphlet form.— I called at the dusk of Evening at Mr W. S. Smith’s— He returned from his visit to Kinderton this morning; but neither he nor Mrs Smith was at home— I received a Letter from the Commissioner of the general Land-Office; with Josiah Savil junrs. Letter, but not answering his enquiries—
24. IV:45. Tuesday

Fahrenheit at 82.— The weather has been several days very fine, but at high Summer heat. This morning I visited Mrs Madison, who has come to take up her residence in this city— I had not seen her since March 1809.— The depredations of time are not so perceptible in her personal appearance, as might be expected— She is a woman of placid, equable temperament, and less susceptible of laceration by the scourges of the world abroad, than most others— The term of her husband’s presidency was tempestuous, and turbulent; but he weathered the storm by that equanimity which carried him also through an eventful period, and a boisterous age— The two closing years of his presidency terminated his political life, with honour—and tranquility—eminently successful in its general result, and glorious individually to him— The succeeding twenty years she
she has passed in retirement—so long as he lived, with him, and now upwards of a year since his decease— She intended to have removed to this place last Autumn, but was prevented by an inflammatory disease in her eyes, from which she has almost wholly recovered— There is no trace of it in her appearance now. Mrs Kearney and Sally Forrest were there—A Son and daughter of Mr Richard Cutts, and a young girl, who came with her from Virginia— I went next to the Pension Office, and on my way saw the procession of the fire companies, from Georgetown to the Navy yard, passing through, and coming out from the President’s yard— It was respectable; but the procession of the fire companies in Boston, which I had seen when Edward Everett delivered his Eulogy on La Fayette, at Faneuil Hall, took off much of the splendour of this— They understand all ceremonials of popular exhibition better in Boston than in any other place on the face of the globe— For Military displays— St. Petersburgh is the place.— At the Pension Office I found Dr Crump— I had the Letter of Mr John Thomas of Marshfield with me; and was to make enquiries, concerning the revolutionary Services of Major General John Thomas, stated by his Son, to have joined the Army in April 1775 and to have died in Canada in June 1776— Dr. Crump found in the Journals of the Continental Congress in March 1776 an entry of a Resolution, directing General Washington to order Brigadier General John Thomas to Canada—and another promoting him to the rank of Major General with an order for making out his Commission— The doctor said he thought some further information might be found in the papers of General Washington at the Department of State— I went there accordingly and saw Mr Forsyth. The name of General Thomas was immediately found in the first muster roll of General Washington’s army at Cambridge, in July 1775. and Mr Forsyth promised to have the papers thoroughly examined for any further evidence which they may contain, relating to Genl. Thomas, and to write me a note of the result. I conversed also with Mr Forsyth upon our relations with Mexico, which are still very precarious. A Mexican Envoy Extraordinary Francisco Pizarro Martinez arrived here a few days since, with a Mr Basave, and a Mr Cos, attached to his legation. They had visited me by Cards, and I had returned their visits in the same way— Mr Forsyth told me that the Minister had not been received. He further told me, that Mr Powhatan Ellis, appointed last Spring as Envoy Extraordinary, and Minister Plenipotentiary to Mexico, was not gone, and would not go, until some disavowal should be made by the Mexican Government, of the outrageous conduct of Mr Gorostiza, upon his leaving this Country— I asked him, if it was his publication of the correspondence— He said, partly that— But the latest accounts he said from Mexico were, the marching of a body of troops, against Santa-Anna, who was intrenched somewhere with 600 men.— He spoke too of Dickson, or Montezuma the second, the adventurer whose project was to put himself of the Mexican Indians and march from California, to Mexico— There are contradictory accounts in the Newspapers of his having been killed, and of his being actually on his march— Forsyth spoke also laughingly, about Houston the President of the Republic of Texas, who is said to be about to resign, and take the command of the army to invade Mexico— He said further that the person in South-Carolina, most sensitive about the annexation of Texas to this Union was James Hamilton, who was said at one time was to supplant Houston in the command of the Texian army
army. I told Mr Forsyth it was probable I might be obliged to make another call for documents at the next Session, but he said there was nothing to communicate— There is a film of obscurity and a squint of duplicity over this whole concern— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were here this Evening— I had called at their house, but they were out. He went only to Kinderton, on his late excursion—not to New-York— I met Dr Huntt, who told me that the President, with Poinsett, Dickerson, and Amos Kendall, went off this morning to Berkley Springs in Virginia.
25. IV. Wednesday.

Day of my father’s marriage— I received a distressing Letter from my wife— She and three of the children were ill— It gave me a bitter heartache— I answered her Letter and sent her an order upon Alpheus Spear— Harvey was here about his bill for Coal, and I asked him to wait a couple of weeks.— In the Pennsylvania avenue I met Dr Everett of Virginia, who during the latter part of Mr Monroe’s administration was his private Secretary— I had not seen him for several years, and thought I had heard he was gone to Europe; but he told me he had not been out of Virginia— I stopped at the Franklin Insurance Coy: Office, and ordered a Policy of Insurance to be made out in the name of Mrs John Adams, upon her House, in which we live—to commence from the 1st. of Novr— I have left it uninsured now, nearly two years; and do not think it safe for her to neglect it longer— I sat about an hour to Mrs Towle for my portrait and she requested a second sitting for this day week.— She says she was a pupil of Harding’s, but she is of a lower order of skill as an artist. Her likenesses are strong, but they have the sign post hardness of outline— I went to the Capitol-Office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives— Mr Burch there— He was occupied in correcting the proof of the last sheet of the Journal of the House at the last Session— I took out two papers left of those which had accompanied the petition of the late William Otis, presented by me in June 1836. He had withdrawn his petition and the other papers, but these had been accidentally left— One of them was a very long list of witnesses, whom he wished to have summoned as witnesses to his claim— I took these papers to Mr Lewis Johnson, the administrator upon William Otis’s estate, and advised him with regard to the preparation of a petition to be presented at the next Session of Congress. I called twice at the Exchange Office of Major Nourse, and there first saw Mr. R. Cutts and afterwards Major Nourse himself, who had just returned from Philadelphia— Met there also Mr John C. Brodhead, a member of Congress from New-York—and in the Street I met Governor Miller of Arkansas also a member of the House, who told me he remained here during the recess, because he had not time to go home and come back for the Winter Session— I called at the dusk of Evening at Mr W. S. Smith’s, and spent an hour with them— In the Evening task of writing out my speech upon Nouns, Pronouns, Verbs and Adverbs, I was overpowered by drowsiness, and forced to suspend the labour till to-morrow. In these turns I drop into sleep with the pen in my hands—
26. V. Thursday

After a long succession of dry and beautiful weather, and a week resembling the last week in July more than the fourth week in October, the change has come in rain, though not cold the whole of this day— Morning visit from Mr Fendall, who said there was to be this Evening a Meeting of the American Historical Society, and he wished to be enabled to inform them whether I could engage to deliver their annual address in January.— I told him, I could not yet positively say— My engagements were yet such, that I had not time
time so much as to survey the subject— It would be safest for the Society to assume that it will not be in my power to comply with their invitation, and to provide themselves with another Orator— But I was very unwilling positively to decline— If they would wait a week or ten days longer, and then receive my answer I would in the mean time make up definitively my mind— He promised at all events to send me the Constitution of the Society and the two preceding annual Addresses by Governors Cass and Woodbury, which if I do undertake the charge it will be necessary for me to peruse— I incline strongly to deliver this address; but my labour of the head and of the hand is slow—during the Session of Congress, this Diary, in despite of every possible exertion of mine, to keep it up, ran twelve days in arrear— From the hour of the adjournment my morning task has been to retrieve the record, and that is not yet completed though within two days of it— At the same time my evening labour, is to write out my speech of Saturday the 14th. on the Bill for adjusting the remaining balances due by the late deposit Banks— Eight hours at least of each day, I sit pen in hand, engaged upon these two works, and at my age, Nature will bear no more. Newspapers, Letters, exercise; food, sleep, and overstrained weariness consume the remaining sixteen hours, and I bless an ever merciful Providence that my health and cheerfulness are yet preserved.— Last evening, I was forced by irresistible drowsiness to leave my nightly task half finished and go to bed— The foul weather of this day enabled me to redeem what I then lost— I omitted the usual exercise of the morning, but at the dusk of evening walked in the rain, to the National Intelligencer Office; but Mr Seaton was not there— Mr Fendall spoke to me of James H. Causten’s Memorial against the President and Directors of the Bank of the Metropolis; and of the injunction issued by Judge Thruston, to Causten and his Son, to stay proceedings, on writs issued by C. H. W. Wharton a Justice of the Peace against the Bank, for refusing payment of their bills— He said he was counsel for the younger Causten— That J. P. Van Ness the President of the Bank of the Metropolis had applied first to Judge Cranch for the injunction, but he would not grant it— He then applied to judge Thruston who did grant it; but he expected the injunction would be dissolved— He said that one of the reasons assigned by the Bill of the Bank was that the Magistrate who issued the writ, upon the 5 dollar bills had no jurisdiction, and that he supposed the ground of this was that Corporations were not liable to process by attachment but only by summons—and if this plea is available, the banks of the District, are not amenable to any tribunal for sums of less than 50 dollars— This is to be remembered.
27. V. Friday

I received this morning a Letter from my wife, which greatly relieved me from an oppressive burden of distress— She says that both children are better— That they propose, if the weather will permit to leave Quincy next Monday— That she may stop one day at New-York to wait for Elizabeth C. Adams, who is at Fishkill landing, and is coming on with her; and that she hopes to meet me at Baltimore— I walked to the Capitol—part of the way with Mr Watterston, with whom I fell in.— He spoke to me of the Southern Confederation, or Convention held atin Georgia, the proceedings of which, he said were in the Merchant, Duff Green’s paper of this day— At the office of the Clerk of the House, I saw Mr Burch
Burch, and Mr Frost.— The Journal of the House for the last Session, is not yet received— Nor was the original Memorial from Halifax Virginia, there.— I looked over a file of the Documents of the last Session, and was surprized to find one Memorial praying for a National Bank, reprinted I believe 20 times over, because it came totidem verbis from so many different places— I wish to examine the file to prepare for the approaching Session of Congress which may probably be my last political trial in this world— I look towards it, as towards a crisis in the affairs of the human race; and in the events of which my last appearance upon the stage of action is to be had, and for all efficient operation I am to close the drama with the day— Whatever of life may be afterwards allotted to me by a merciful Providence must be to glide down the stream, under the guidance of others— On my way home I stop’d at the Office of the National Intelligencer and saw Mr Seaton— I saw there too the Janus-face Merchant, and Reformer—published by Duff Green, at the same time in Baltimore, by the name of the Merchant, and here, by that of the Reformer— And I read the proceedings of the Southern Convention— The report of the Committee by George M’Duffie; and the Resolutions of the Convention, including that for the meeting of another Convention next April— Here is the germ of a Southern Convention with South-Carolina at its head which is to divide this Union into a Northern a Southern and a Western Confederacy, with Texas and a fourth part of Mexico, annexed to the confederacy of the South— The movement of Calhoun in the Senate and of Pickens in the House is obviously combined with this project, which is offensive as regards the North American Union, and defensive against the progress of the Abolition of Slavery.— The National Intelligencer of this day contains the first part of Mr Mercer’s Speech, against the Bill to postpone the fourth instalment, of the deposit with the States, under the Act of 23 June 1836. the remainder of the Speech will be printed to-morrow.— It will contain fifteen columns of the paper; and is the first great Speech that Mercer has made for the last ten years— Mine on the bill for adjusting the balances with the Banks, is substantially upon the same subject— It is less elaborate than his and will occupy not more than two thirds so much space of the paper— The present the question upon the two Bills in different lights; and will be important, when the question comes up at the next Session of Congress as it must for a further postponement of the instalment— I spent an hour of the Evening with Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith— They had a fire in the upper front chamber, but none below. I gave Mrs Smith a Letter from Mrs T. B. Adams declining her invitation to come and pass the winter with her— Mr Smith, promised to call on me to-morrow morning.— There is great agitation in the public mind, by reports of a Ship Susquehanna, from Philadelphia, having been taken last Saturday by a piratical Schooner off the Capes of Delaware— The arrears of my Diary at this time are now closed.
28. VI. Saturday

Mr Smith was here twice: first in the morning, when I gave him the Letter from Josiah Savil junr. and the Letter from the Commissioner, of the general Land Office, and requested him to ascertain if there was at the Office any record or file of papers received from my late brother Thomas relating to a Land patent in the name of Charles Newcomb or of Josiah Savil— At 3. O’Clock he came again, and said there was no trace on the records or on the files, of any such correspondence, or of Land Patents issued in either of those names. I received a Letter from Richard
Richard Pollard, dated Santiago de Chile, 26. July 1837.with copies of Letters one to General Samuel Houston, President of the Republic of Texas dated 21. April, and one to the Editors of the National Intelligencer, of the Globe and others of 25. April 1837. all complaining that his Son, a youth of 19. who had joined the Texian army to fight in the cause of Liberty, had been murdered— That is, he had been shot in the head in a duel, and by harsh usage in transporting him, in a march of the troops, he had died under the operation— There has already been something of this in the Newspapers— I received also a Letter from Baring brothers to the Executors of Ward N. Boylston—acknowledging the receipt of £2000 sterling from Petty Vaughan, upon our Bill of Exchange of the 11th. of August last— Proof positive that my remarks upon him then were hasty—and too severe. There was in the National Intelligencer of this morning an Advertisement again of the Sale of a Woman and two children, at 11. O’Clock— I went between 11 and 12 O’Clock to the room, the woman and children, girls of 7 and 9 years of age were there, the woman weeping and wailing most piteously. I enquired of Dyer if they were sold— He said no— That they had been sold last Monday, and bought in by the husband of the woman who was free, and a waiter at Gadsby’s—he had bought them in for 475 dollars, but was unable to raise the money, which was the reason why they were to be sold again— They were waiting for the man, who was endeavouring to procure by subscription, upon his own engagement to repay the money, the means of paying for his purchase last Monday— Mr F. S. Key the District Attorney came in, and appeared to interest himself in favour of the man— I learnt from Dyer, that the woman had been the Slave of a white woman who had married a man named Davis who lived at Georgetown, and was a Clerk in the War Department— That this white woman had died, and had before her death, promised Dorcas her freedom— That on her death bed, she had made her husband Davis promise her that he would emancipate Dorcas— That he did actually liberate her, but gave her no papers— That she lived twelve or fifteen years at large—married, and had four children— That in the meantime Davis married a second wife, and afterwards died without granting to Dorcas her papers of freedom— That Davis’s widow, married a man by the name of Rezin Orme, and that he sold Dorcas and her four children, on the 22d. of August last for 700 dollars to Birch who is an agent for the negro Slave-traders at Alexandria— That Dorcas and her four children, were on the same day removed to one of the Slave prisons in Alexandria— That in the Night of that day, she killed the two youngest of her children, one a boy four years of age, and the other a girl under twelve months— That she attempted to kill the other two, but was prevented; their screaming having roused some person in the house, who went into the cell where she was confined, and took her surviving children from her— That she was tried at Alexandria for the murder of her two children and was acquitted by the Jury, on the ground of insanity— These were stated as the facts, and it was said to be doubtful whether Rezin Orme, had any right to sell them at all. Mr Key made some enquiries about Orme, who it was said had left the District, and was not to be found—and about Mrs Orme, who he said was under obligations to him; but who Dyer said had shut herself up in her chamber and would be seen by no person on the subject. Mr
Mr Key called me out of the Auction room to speak in private with me on the subject; he said he thought a subscription might be raised to enable Allen to pay for the purchase of his wife, and children; and I told him I would give fifty dollars towards it— I then called upon judge Cranch at his Office in the City Hall—and enquired of him concerning the trial of this woman at Alexandria— He read to me his Notes at the trial— There were two Indictments against her; one for the murder of each of her children— She was tried only upon one— That of the boy— The evidence of her killing them was complete— The defence was insanity— Not the slightest evidence of insanity at the time, except the mere fact of her killing the children— There was evidence of her being subject to fits, which sometimes lasted an hour— That she is passionate, and violent, and some times wild in her talk— The jury acquitted her as insane— The prosecutor entered a noli prosequi upon the second indictment— Upon being asked why she had killed her children, she said they were in Heaven—that if they had lived she did not know what would have become of them— That her mistress had been wrong—that her mistress was a methodist; and so she was herself— There was no evidence before the court, of any thing, preceding the acts for which she was tried— I enquired of the judge concerning the case between the Causten’s, and the bank of the Metropolis— He said Van Ness had applied to him for an injunction which he had refused; believing that there was no equity for Chancery interposition, in the case— Van Ness had afterwards applied to judge Thruston, who granted the injunction; but told judge Cranch that when he granted it, he did not know it had been refused by him— He said that if Justices of the Peace had no jurisdiction in pleas of debt against corporations, the jurisdiction even for debts under 50 dollars, must remain with the Circuit Court. The judge said he had declined conversing with Causten upon the subject— I asked the judge his opinion upon the expediency of abolishing imprisonment for debt in the district— He said it was virtually abolished by the facility of obtaining a release in cases of insolvency— I spoke of the sale of free Negroes for jail fees— He said there was great need of a revision of the Laws respecting runaway negroes— He gave me his copy, with marginal annotations of Mr Alexander’s Report on Slavery in the District of Columbia of 29. Jany. 1829. and spoke of a much fuller report by Gershom Powers in Feby. 1830. On leaving the judge I called at the Office of the National Intelligencer, but Gales and Seaton were both absent— Then again at Dyer’s auction room, but he was absent, and the Negro woman and children were gone— Then at Mr Force, the Mayor’s Office and he was absent— Home—walk at the dusk of evening. Letter to J. Meredith, Baltimore— Speech of 14. October— Shivering cold—

29. V:15. Sunday— Fahrenheit 50.— Morning service at the Presbyterian Church. Dr Laurie and Mr Fowler both officiated the former in prayer and the latter by the Sermon— Mr And Mrs Nourse were not present— Mr Fowler’s text was from 2 Corinthians 5.8. “We are confident, I say, and willing rather to be absent from the body, and to be present with the Lord.” A funeral Sermon upon a Lady, a member of that Church, deceased in the course of the last week, whom the preacher did not name, but of whose last illness and death and of the pious resigna and religious fervour with which she suffered he spoke with much earnestness and sensibility— Dr Laurie in his prayer had noticed the recent death of two Ladies
Ladies, one of whom did not belong to this Church— Before the close of the Service he announced that Mrs Larned died yesterday—and that her funeral would be to-morrow morning at 11. O’Clock, when the Congregation were invited to attend— After dinner at St. John’s Church, Mr Miller, who Mr Hawley told me was for the present located at the Rock Creek Church, officiated— He read with uncommon propriety, the Evening Service for the 23d. Sunday after Trinity, omitting the absolution.— His Sermon, a very good one was from 1. Kings 18.21. [“]And Elijah came unto all the People and said,— How long halt ye between two opinions? if the Lord be God, follow him; but if Baal, then follow him. And the people answered him not a word”— He gave out only the question omitting the first and last part of the verse— But he related the story of the contest between Elijah and the priests of Baal, and its issue, with great spirit, and a wonderful story it is— The confidence with which Elijah proposes the trial—the readiness with which it is accepted by the Priests of Baal— The sincerity with which they appear to have expected that Baal would vindicate his claim to Godhead— The insulting mockery of Elijah, standing alone against the 450 prophets of Baal, and the 400 prophets of the groves—the slaughter of the 450 false prophets by the single hand of Elijah;—every one of these incidents is as marvelous, and as remote from any possibility of the present age, as the miraculous fire from Heaven which consumed the altar at the command of Elijah— At the present day, no Christian Minister would dare to propose as the test of the truth of his religion, the performance of a miracle— No one would dare accept such a proposal if made to him by the Priest of another religion— The true religion is not tested by the performance of miracles, and it must be admitted that when it was, the miracles were never followed by any permanent effect upon the belief or practice of the People— Mr Miller’s discourse was a powerful argument against the folly and wickedness of halting between two opinions—a great weakness in morals and politics, as it is a sin in religion— The weather was so cold that I was obliged to have a fire made this evening in my chamber— Wrote to my Co-executors Mr Curtis, and Mrs Boylston.
30. V:45. Monday

Mr Fowler, the Minister of the second Presbyterian Church—with Mr. M’Masters another Clergyman of the same denomination who preached there yesterday afternoon, paid me a morning visit— The Lady who was the subject of Mr Fowler’s funeral eulogy yesterday morning was Miss Smith, a daughter of Samuel Harrison Smith’s, who died last week— Mrs Larned was of the Episcopal Church, though her husband was of the Presbyterian— I received a Letter from Mr Meredith of Baltimore, with information that the case of Reuben M. Whitney vs Leakin and Barnes, was last Saturday referred, at his proposal, with an agreement that if the referees do not make an award before the 1st. of May next, the suit shall be discontinued— The Counsel for the defendants had obtained proof from Montreal, that Whitney took two Oaths during the late war with Great Britain—one, that which he acknowledged upon my examination of him before the Bank investigation Committee in 1832—the other afull and unqualified Oath of Allegiance, special against the United States of America; and that he was a contractor, for the British army which invaded the United States during
during the whole of the War— Treason and perjury are thus fastened upon him, beyond all possibility of reply; Treason during the War; and perjury, in his answers to my enquiries on the Bank investigation— And this is the man who whispered into Andrew Jackson’s heart that mixture of hatred and revenge against Nicholas Biddle, which spurred him to the removal of the deposits, to his undying rage against the Bank of the United States, and to that hurling of firebrands into the community which has reduced the Country to its present condition. I called at Dyer’s auction room to enquire what had been done with Dorcas Allen and her two children on Saturday. He was not there; but a man in his place told me that Mr Key and Birch had made some arrangement by which the woman had been taken by her husband, and the two children had been taken away by Birch— I then called at the Office of the National Intelligencer, and saw Mr Seaton— I spoke to him of the Letters from Mr Richard Pollard, complaining of the murder of his Son, in Texas— Seaton said he had received months ago the Letter to the Editors of the Globe, Intelligencer and others of 25. April 1837. with the copy of the Letter to Genl. Samuel Houston, President of the Texian Republic— And that last Friday he had received duplicates of the same Letters— That they had published nothing in the National Intelligencer on the subject—because the Globe had published the Letters, because the young man appeared to have died in consequence of a duel; because this was but one of daily hundreds of proofs that the Texians were no better than a lawless banditti, and because if they were to publish the Letters, the parties accused in Texas might answer in the same style with the complaint and involve the paper in a very unprofitable and useless controversy— I told Mr Seaton I was not yet prepared with my speech of the 14th. I met in the Street, Mr Force the Mayor; who said Mr Fendall had asked him to send me the Constitution of the American historical Society, and the Discourses of the Governors Cass and Woodbury, which he would do— There was no meeting of the Society last Thursday; it having been prevented by the stormy weather— I spent an hour of the Evening at Mr W. S. Smith’s, and breakfasted and dined in my chamber— Scattered some of my time, in endeavours to arrange my books, and in poring over Congressional documents, which I ought yet more closely to study— Richard Pollard, is the Chargé d’Affaires of the United States in Chili.
31. V:45— Tuesday

A cold night again; and unsound repose— Like David in his old age, though they cover me with clothes I get no heat— Mrs Franzoni came this morning and requested my influence to obtain a place in one of the public Offices for her son— She is the widow of an Italian Sculptor, once an artist at the Capitol, and one of the most skilful among them— He lived in a house adjoining that of Daniel Brent in which I then resided, and died very suddenly one morning in 1819. or 20. to the extreme distress and consternation of this woman and her family— I saw him dead in his house, within half an hour after he expired— I was under the impression that she had returned to Europe, but she has not; and this Son of hers an infant between two and three years of age then, is now a man of 21. She says he has been brought up as a printer at Philadelphia—that he writes well, and is capable of performing the duties of a Clerk in any of the public Offices
Offices; and that her chief dependence for support is upon him— I asked her to send him to me to morrow morning, that I may talk with him, and said if an opportunity should present itself in which I can serve him, I would do so. Mr R. R. Gurley a Secretary of the Colonization Society likewise called upon me. He mentioned that he had it in Contemplation to set up here a periodical journal partly religious and partly political, but chiefly to promote the objects and views of the Colonization Society— He professed at the same time an unqualified approbation of my course in Congress, upon the subject of Texas and of the right of petition— I told him that I was much gratified at having the assurance of his approbation upon my conduct, on trying questions— That my own views, with regard to the abolition of Slavery throughout the United States, concurred more with those which I understood to be avowed by the leading members of the Colonization Society, than with those of the Abolition and Anti-Slavery Societies in General— But that to be frank and candid with him, I did not think it possible that a paper, to be conducted on the principles which he had exposed could be sustained within this place. It would be, as the Colonization Society itself is obnoxious to both the opposite parties—to the abolitionists, and to the Slave-holders— I believed there would henceforth be no middle term between them— After a long conversation with him, which more fully confirmed me in these opinions, he left me, apparently not convinced by my remarks, but admitting that he had little to say in reply to them— He has recently returned from a residence for a considerable time in Georgia, and much intercourse with the other Southern States— He gave me an account of the opinions generally prevailing among them, corresponding with the impressions which I had previously entertained— But he said the members of Congress from the Southern States did not exactly represent the feelings of their constituents, and particularly of the religious portion of them— Of this I was well aware— Mr Gurley asked me for a copy of my Oration at Newbury-Port, and of my Speech of 25. May 1836. on the Rations or Texas Question, both of which I gave him— Walk to the Capitol— Met Mr Hall, who is going to Boston, for Mr Lewis Johnson, to take testimony concerning the claims of the late William Otis, and who asked for my advice which I gave him. Met also Edward Wyer, who promised me again a budget of Speeches, and told me that of all vulgar men in this world, the most vulgar man in his judgment was the Vice President of the United States— Wyer is doorkeeper to the Senate— At the Clerk’s Office of the House, I found only Mr Frost, who gave me a copy of the Journals of the House at the last Session; and the original Anti-Abolition Memorial from Halifax Virginia.— I did not go out after dinner, but continued writing and examining documents till eleven at night endeavouring in vain to finish my Speech

Day— The first half of the Month till the 16th. like the preceding month— Since the close of the Session of Congress, my labours have relaxed themselves. My rising is from 4 to 6. and for several days past, not till the dawn of day— The middle of the day and the dusk of Evening I give to exercise abroad—to walking, and calls of business— My evenings to the writing out of my Speech on the Evening of the 14th.— Toil and Trust.— [symbols]
